titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. A violent storm all the former part of the day.— In the afternoon it cleared up, cold— I went in the afternoon to Mr: Whitney’s, where my books sent from Holland have been kept for some years; unpack’d two of the boxes; took out the books and sent them down to my father’s. Spent the Evening, in writing— This day the election for Members of the House of Representatives of the United States was held throughout the Commonwealth— My father attended the meeting at Quincy, where the votes were for Mr: Everett 62—for Mr: Seaver 12— He was there inform’d, that in Boston there was a majority of 66 votes for me— And as the Majority in the other towns which are annexed to Boston to form the district will undoubtedly be more than a balance for it, Dr: Eustis is unquestionably re-elected to represent the District.

2. The weather this day is fair and cold— Return’d to Boston with my family.— Met Mr: Gardner at Milton— On reaching Boston, I transacted some business at the Union-Bank— Rest of the day at my Office— In the afternoon, and again in the Evening called upon Mr: Sullivan the Attorney-General— On the subject of the Chancery Cause, Graves vs the Insurance Company.— Mrs: Adams excessively ill, the whole day, after getting home, with a sick head-ache.
3. The result of the election in this District stands thus.

So that Dr: Eustis stands re-elected by a majority of 59 votes— The cause assigned by the federalists for their failure is that the election day was rainy, and that a large number of strong federal votes from the remotest part of the town was lost, by non-attendance— This is one of a thousand proofs, how large a portion of federalism is a mere fair-weather principle, too weak to overcome a shower of rain— It shews the degree of dependence that can be placed upon such friends.— As a party, their adversaries are more sure, and more earnest— For myself, I must consider the issue as relieving me from an heavy burden, and a thankless task. I Pass’d the day, chiefly at my Office— Attended club in the evening at Mr: Smith’s.

4. Pass’d the forenoon partly at my Office, and partly at that of the Commissioners of Bankrupts, where we finally took the surrender of Roylance Child— My mother and Mrs: Cranch came to town, and dined with us— They returned in the afternoon— A Short time at my Office, and spent the Evening at home— Read the 10th: book of Paradise Lost.

5. Busily engaged in various business all the forenoon— Dined at Mr: S. Elliot’s in company with a number of Gentlemen— Left them immediately after dinner to attend the funeral of my old friend N. Frazier, who died in the night of the first instt: after a lingering illness, which commenced last February.— In the evening, met at Mr: Emerson’s with the Society for the study of natural philosophy, of which he was a member— The principal object of this meeting was to agree upon some arrangements for resuming our meetings weekly— We came to no final determination, but are to meet again at the President’s, (Judge Davis’s) next Friday— Mr: S. P. Gardner was admitted as a member.

6. Purchased of Charles Nolen, an house in Half-Court Square— Received his deed, and lodged it, in the Register’s Office to be recorded— Drew a bill of exchange on Bird, Savage & Bird in favour of Dr: Danforth— Wrote them a letter of notice, which I lodg’d in the Post-Office to go by the Warrington. Mr: Black took me out to Quincy with him in the afternoon— Mr: T. K. Jones applied for a writ, which I drew and gave Mr: Bell the Depy: Sheriff to be served.

7. Began reading Plutarch’s Instructions to Statesmen, which being long, I read but partly through— Heard Mr: Simpkins of Harwich, who dined with us— Read also the correspondence between Junius and Sir William Draper— My uncle Adams and Captain Beale spent the evening with us.

8. Return’d to Boston, early this morning in the chaise with Dexter— Mr: Gardner called at my Office— Pass’d the day, chiefly in examining the laws respecting the laying out of high-ways— Jo: Hall came and spent the Evening with us— Play’d a game of chess with him.

9. Went to Dedham early this morning— Argued the two causes of the petitions for roads in Quincy, and through Walpole and Wrentham.— In the first I was alone as Counsel— Mr: Ames and B. Whitman, for the petitioners. The trial took the whole forenoon— And after dinner untill Sunset— There were twenty Justices on the Bench.— The votes were 9 for the road and 10 against it— The Chief Justice—Warren, would have voted also for it, could his vote have altered the decision— The report of the Committee in favour of the road was therefore the rejected— In the Wrentham cause, the report was of a locating Committee— Mr: Dexter was with me, for the petitioners— Wheaton, Whitman and Ames against us; and prevailed— The papers were quashed for irregularity— The votes were eleven and seven— One Justice, besides Mr: Warren, not voting.— It was past 9 in the evening when these causes were finished and the Court adjourn’d— But the weather being fine and the moon bright I concluded to return this night to Boston— When I had got about 3 miles on the road, one of the wheels of my Chaise came off, and drop’d me in the middle of the way. Thanks to a kind Providence, without injury to myself— It was now 10 at night— A couple of men who soon came along with a cart, helped me to get my wheel on again, and fix’d it sufficiently to lead my horse as far as Major Whiting’s tavern, about a quarter of a mile further on the road— There I put up for the night, to have my chaise repaired in the morning before I proceed any farther.

10. Sent my chaise early this morning to a blacksmith’s; and had the wheel repaired— After breakfasting I proceeded on my way home, which I reached between 10 and 11 o’clock— Transacted some business in the forenoon with John Jackson, and at the Union Bank— Mr: Walter who has just returned from Washington, called at the beginning of the Evening, and took tea with us.— Club at Dr: Spooner’s. The fullest we have had for many months—

11. Pass’d the day principally at my Office— First ball this Evening— Mrs: Adams and Caroline intended to have gone, but Mrs: A. in the afternoon being unwell concluded to stay— Spent the Evening at home— Read the 11th: book of Paradise Lost— Mr: G. H. Apthorp called at my Office on business. Settled an account with Frothingham—

12. Writing at my Office all the forenoon— After dinner went and took a ride with Mr: Hall— Over West-Boston bridge, and round through Cambridge, Brookline and Roxbury, into town by the Neck— Spent the Evening with the Society at Judge Davis’s— We are to take up the subject of Chemistry— To meet next week at Mr: Quincy’s.

13. Employed almost the whole forenoon, away from my Office— Mr: G. Apthorp called there, but I had not finished his business— Dined with Mr: Otis— Company of about fifteen Gentlemen— Left the table between 5 and 6. Went out to Quincy with Mr: Gardner.
14. Heard Mr: Whitney— Read the remainder of Plutarch’s Instructions to Statesmen, and some letters of Junius— My Uncle Adams dined with us;— Company in the Evening.

15. Returned to Boston this morning— Dr: Tufts called upon me just before dinner, and I could not attend to his business— Mr: Shaw did it for him— Mr: Babcock, Mr: Dexter, Mr: Smith, Mr: G. Greene, Mr: T. C. Amory, Mr: Quincy, and Mr: J. Gore dined with us— Several others whom I had invited failed. In the evening, went with Mrs: Adams & Caroline to Mr: Smith’s— Saw there Mr: Sheaffe late a Senator of the United States from New-Hampshire.

16. Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy with Mr: Walter, and pass’d the day— I spent it at my Office. Made a report with Mr: Quincy, upon the admission of Mr: Dutton to the Court of Common Pleas; to be proposed next April, and admitted in July— Drew up likewise a report for the meeting of the Academy to-morrow, upon the proposal received from the agricultural Society of New-York. Called at Dr: Dexter’s, for his signature— But he expects to attend the meeting and will sign it, if necessary there— Judge Davis had call’d on me about it in the morning— Evening at home— Read to the Ladies the 12th: Book of Paradise Lost, and some pages in the second Volume of Burke’s works.

17. My father came into town this morning, and went to Cambridge to attend the meeting of the Academy. I went up with Judge Davis— The weather was unpleasant, and the meeting was not sufficiently numerous for transacting any business— After the meeting, I went with my father to Judge Dana’s, where we dined. Mrs: Channing and Mr: W. Ellery were there.— Immediately after dinner we return’d to Boston; where my father stay’d the night— Mrs: & Miss Otis, the Miss Storers, and Mr: Smith were here in the Evening.

18. My father return’d this morning to Quincy— I pass’d the day at my Office, principally writing. Spent the evening untill 9. at Mr: S. Higginson junrs.— A large company of ladies and gentlemen— We had music and cards— Thence we went to the Assembly, which was not numerous— Play’d cards there again, and danced after supper— Came home soon after 11. o’clock.

19. Forenoon at my Office— Mr: Gardner called— Dined at Judge Dawes’s with several gentlemen.— Came home early in the evening— Found Mrs: Adams had been unwell.— Spent the Evening at Mr: Quincy’s in making arrangements for pursuing the subject of chemistry.
20. Spent the forenoon idly at my Office— Mr: Gardner called there; and in the afternoon, I went with him out to Quincy— Mrs: Adams still unwell— Began this morning to look into the chemical books.

21. Read Plutarch’s treatise upon the question whether old men should meddle with public affairs. Heard Mr: Ware of Hingham; upon tenderness of heart— General Knox came out and dined with us— In the evening I return’d with him to Boston— Mrs: Adams had been bled in the course of the day— Read a little in Burke— Began upon his Vindication of natural Society.

22. Find myself unwell, with a rheumatism,— Mr: George H. Apthorp called at my Office this forenoon. Spent the principal part of the day in Court—hearing a trial before the District Court; on a case of bankruptcy— Evening at home— Read Burke’s letter to the Sheriffs of Bristol— Upon the American War— I had never read it before.

23. Recovered in a great measure from the rheumatism of yesterday— Spent the day at my Office—principally in writing— At Quincy’s Office, and conversed with him and Dr: Jackson, upon the subject of Dr: Danforth’s chemical apparatus— Evening at home— Read Burke’s two letters to Gentlemen in Bristol; and part of his Speech upon the oeconomical reform.

24. Forenoon at my Office, employed in various business. Mr: Shaw went out of town with Mr: Gardner: In the afternoon I went to Quincy, alone— Mrs: Adams was not well enough to go— Caroline stay’d in town to keep her company.

25. Thanksgiving day.— Heard Mr: Whitney, whose sermon was somewhat political— It screw’d one or two of the malignant brotherhood out of the house— Mr: and Mrs: Cranch, Mrs: Smith, and Mr: Norton’s five boys dined with us. I pass’d the remainder of the day chiefly in writing, at the Office.

26. Mr: Shaw having a severe cold and cough, remains at Quincy untill Monday— I return’d to Boston this morning with the two Maids. Stop’d at Dorchester—Mr: Cogswells and contracted for 15000 bricks, to be sent for my father— Cogswell says from 7 to 10,000 are the usual number for a stack of chimnies. These the large sized bricks at $6 1/2 per thousand— After reaching town and passing the day, writing at my Office— Spent
the evening with the Society for the Study of Natural History, at Quincy’s Office— We are still under several embarassments relative to a room, and to the plan upon which we should proceed— Came to no final determination— Elected Mr: J. Lowell a member of the Society.

27. Spent the day at my Office— Mr: Gardner called upon me this forenoon; and again towards evening. Read in the second volume of Blackstone— In the evening, read at home Burke’s Speech at the Guildhall at Bristol.

28. Heard Mr: Thacher this morning at our own Church, and Mr: Hedge, I think in the afternoon, in Brattle-Street— Walk’d with George in the Mall— Evening at home; and read part of Burke’s Speech, on Mr: Fox’s India Bill.

29. Forenoon uninterrupted at my Office— Read Blackstone— In the afternoon attended the funeral of Mrs: Spooner— Expecting letters from my brother at Philadelphia, but received none.— Evening at the play—Abaellino— They say, but not truly, from Schiller.— And no song no supper— It was over by 10. at night, House full:

30. Spent the day at my Office and part of the Evening— Principally writing— Received a letter and remittance from my brother, this evening— Latter part of it, at home, reading still Burke’s speech upon the India-Bill; which is long— Did not quite finish it.
Day. As the last Month— Excepting the attendance at the Courts; none of which have been sitting this month.
